dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener writes in, 'Just read about the paper mache Falcon 9 rocket. Is this for real?'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener writes in, 'Just read about the paper mache Falcon nine rocket. Is this for real?'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it's uh, definitely a real announcement from Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone, the co-founders of that aerospace company.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it's uh, definitely a real announcement from Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone, the co-founders of that aerospace company.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're planning to launch it from an undisclosed desert in Nevada, which is just... wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're planning to launch it from an undisclosed desert in Nevada, which is just... wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its rocket will launch from Cape Canaveral.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they raised, what, five million dollars? For a hot air balloon factory acquisition?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they raised, what, five million dollars? For a hot air balloon factory acquisition?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But then the article says their total investment is only six hundred thousand, so the math is... questionable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But then the article says their total investment is only six hundred thousand, so the math is... questionable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they have no customers, no signed deals. Launches are gonna cost like, half a billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they have no customers, no signed deals. Launches are gonna cost like, half a billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativity already has customers. Launches cost $10 million, in the ballpark of current satellite launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is way more than blimp rentals, even though that market is shrinking anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is way more than blimp rentals, even though that market is shrinking anyway.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're up against companies that have already ceased operations, like Blue Origin? It's a weird space to be in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're up against companies that have already ceased operations, like Blue Origin? It's a weird space to be in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, only one of those companiesthe L.A.-based Rocket Labhas launched commercial payloads to orbit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, they don't even have printers at their facility. How do you build paper mache rockets without printers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, they don't even have printers at their facility. How do you build paper mache rockets without printers?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To that end, the company has built four large 3D-printers, which it calls Stargate, at its manufacturing facility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's all manual, Ellis said. Once engineering is done and the factory closes, they'll produce zero rockets. That's... not ideal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's all manual, Ellis said. Once engineering is done and the factory closes, they'll produce zero rockets. That's... not ideal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nice part of 3D-printing is that once the factory is built and were really scaling launch rate and production rate, it is a significantly more automated process, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet he's already talking about hand-painted cardboard rockets for Venus. The ambition is there, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet he's already talking about hand-painted cardboard rockets for Venus. The ambition is there, I guess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Ambition, yeah, but also maybe a total lack of reality. Elon Musk is their only investor? Through a shell corp?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ambition, yeah, but also maybe a total lack of reality. Elon Musk is their only investor? Through a shell corp?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round, which was led by Noah Knauf at Bond fund and Tribe Capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like something out of a satire piece, but it's in the LA Times.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like something out of a satire piece, but it's in the L A Times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think this is like, performance art? Or just a very expensive joke?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think this is like, performance art? Or just a very expensive joke?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Either way, I wouldn't bet on seeing that paper mache Falcon 9 on the moon anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Either way, I wouldn't bet on seeing that paper mache Falcon nine on the moon anytime soon.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener writes in, 'Just read about the paper mache Falcon 9 rocket. Is this for real?'
HostB: Oh, it's uh, definitely a real announcement from Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone, the co-founders of that aerospace company.
HostA: Yeah, and they're planning to launch it from an undisclosed desert in Nevada, which is just... wild.
HostB: And they raised, what, five million dollars? For a hot air balloon factory acquisition?
HostA: Exactly. But then the article says their total investment is only six hundred thousand, so the math is... questionable.
HostB: Right, and they have no customers, no signed deals. Launches are gonna cost like, half a billion dollars.
HostA: Which is way more than blimp rentals, even though that market is shrinking anyway.
HostB: And they’re up against companies that have already ceased operations, like Blue Origin? It's a weird space to be in.
HostA: Plus, they don't even have printers at their facility. How do you build paper mache rockets without printers?
HostB: I mean, it's all manual, Ellis said. Once engineering is done and the factory closes, they'll produce zero rockets. That’s... not ideal.
HostA: And yet he's already talking about hand-painted cardboard rockets for Venus. The ambition is there, I guess.
HostB: Ambition, yeah, but also maybe a total lack of reality. Elon Musk is their only investor? Through a shell corp?
HostA: It feels like something out of a satire piece, but it’s in the LA Times.
HostB: Do you think this is like, performance art? Or just a very expensive joke?
HostA: Either way, I wouldn’t bet on seeing that paper mache Falcon 9 on the moon anytime soon.
